Comment: If they are violating the constitution that‚Äôs supposedly not pardonable.   Nor can the pardon power be used to prevent courts from enforcing orders protecting constitutional rights. Consider a president who pardoned an individual held in contempt of court. The Supreme Court has held that the judiciary‚Äôs role in our constitutional system hinges on the ability of courts to prosecute contempt independently‚Äîthat is, without relying on the executive branch. Such a pardon would subvert a court‚Äôs ability to enforce its orders, making ‚Äúa mere mockery‚Äù of the judiciary‚Äôs constitutional powers.

Comment: Narcissistic people like Trump thrive on projected power. He wants us to believe that he‚Äôs untouchable, and they work very hard to construct narratives that push such an idea.  It‚Äôs, I think, partly why there‚Äôs this need for *public humiliation* in Trumps inner circle. Like, as someone who may have been a career politician who was in some regard respectable, you‚Äôre faced with an environment now where the longevity of your continued career is defined by how far you can bend the knee and how many mooches you can give the ring. It‚Äôs natural for that to be humiliating, and yet it‚Äôs seemingly a requirement. They need people around Trump who support the image of power he constructs.  Look to the tariffs. Trump said he wasn‚Äôt backing down. But the bond market became ‚Äúyippy,‚Äù and so he folded. We have found Trumps limit there (albeit, a damn far and scary limit). Us knowing that limit is bad for Trump. Trumps strategy requires that we believe he does not have a limit, so that we behave accordingly.   A little beside the point but just to cut even deeper into that example; he wants businesses to treat his tariffs like they‚Äôre a permanent part of integrating with the US economy now. One of the rhetorics he gave was, it should help bring manufacturing jobs back to the US. That‚Äôs obviously not going to work when your plan is fundamentally flawed though, because businesses look to his tariffs and only see uncertainty for the market. They rightfully don‚Äôt trust that Trumps tariffs are worth basing long term decisions on. Instead, they see the tariffs as reason to hold off on long term decisions, spending, and thus: an economic recession is a concern.  Back on point, we need to keep pushing. We have to keep finding where Trumps limits are, so that we can exploit them. You say that Trumps team doesn‚Äôt care about the points I‚Äôve raised, but I‚Äôd argue we‚Äôre pushing things yet further and we haven‚Äôt checked those limits yet. Let‚Äôs check those limits and keep pushing‚Ä¶ this is attrition, not a smoking gun. More important than that though, and contrary to the idea that Trump is all powerful; this is something, not nothing, that we can do.
Author: DuckDatum
